Scorers#

class bert_squeeze.utils.scorers.scorer.LooseScorer(loose_classes: List[List[str | int]])[source]#

Helper class to compute various ‘loose’ evaluation metrics.

For some classification one might be interested in gathering some classes.

E.g. an anomaly detection problem with different severity level: 0: not an anomaly, 1: mild anomaly, 2: anomaly, 3: severe anomaly One could be interested in checking the performance of the loose problem: anomaly/not anomaly. To do so: >>> loose_scorer = LooseScorer(loose_classes=[[0], [1,2,3]])

Parameters:

loose_classes (List[List[Union[str, int]]]) – list of classes to aggregate together during metrics computation

add(logits: Tensor, labels: Tensor, loss: Loss | None | float = None, ignored_label: int = -100) → None[source]#

Updates the confusion matrix by using the predictions and the ground truth labels and keeps track of the loss.

Parameters:

  • logits (torch.Tensor) – predicted logits

  • labels (torch.Tensor) – ground truth labels

  • loss (Union[LossType, float]) – computed loss

  • ignored_label (int) – value to ignore during metric computation, default to -100 (PyTorch ignored value)

class bert_squeeze.utils.scorers.scorer.Scorer(n_labels: int)[source]#

Helper class to compute various evaluation metrics.

This is achieved by updating a confusion matrix after every batch.

Parameters:

n_labels (int) – number of available labels

property acc: float#
Computes the accuracy score:

number of correct predictions / number of predictions

Returns:

accuracy score

Return type:

float

add(logits: Tensor, labels: Tensor, loss: Loss | None | float = None, ignored_label: int = -100) → None[source]#

Updates the confusion matrix by using the predictions and the ground truth labels.

Parameters:

  • logits (torch.Tensor) – predicted logits

  • labels (torch.Tensor) – ground truth labels

  • loss (Union[LossType, float]) – computed loss

  • ignored_label (int) – value to ignore during metric computation, default to -100 (PyTorch ignored value)

property f1: array#
Computes the f1 score for each class using the following formula:

F1 = 2 * (precision * recall) / (precision + recall)

Returns:

f1 score for every class. f1[i] is the f1 score of class i

Return type:

np.array

get_table() → str[source]#

Method to format all the metrics into a pretty table.

Returns:

prettyfied table summarizing all the metrics

Return type:

str

property macro_f1: ndarray#

Computes the unweighted mean of the f1s

Returns:

unweighted mean of the f1s

Return type:

float

property macro_precision: ndarray#

Computes the unweighted mean of the precisions

Returns:

unweighted mean of the precisions

Return type:

float

property macro_recall: ndarray#

Computes the unweighted mean of the recalls

Returns:

unweighted mean of the recalls

Return type:

float

property micro_f1: float#

Counts the total true positives, false negatives and false positives.

Returns:

micro f1

Return type:

float

property micro_precision: float#

Counts the total true positives, false negatives and false positives.

Returns:

micro precision

Return type:

float

property micro_recall: float#

Counts the total true positives, false negatives and false positives.

Returns:

micro recall

Return type:

float

property precision: array#
Computes the precision score for each class using the following formula:

tp / (tp + fp)

Returns:

precision score for every class. precision[i] is the precision score

of class i

Return type:

np.array

property recall: array#
Computes the recall score for each class using the following formula:

tp / (tp + fn)

Returns:

recall score for every class. recall[i] is the recall score

of class i

Return type:

np.array

reset() → None[source]#

Resets the confusion matrix, batch counter and losses. This method should be called after logging metrics.

to_dict() → Dict[str, float][source]#

Returns all the accessible metrics within a dict where the key is the metric name and the value is the metric.

Returns:

dict of metrics

Return type:

Dict[str, float]

property weighted_f1: float#

Computes the f1 for each label, and find their average weighted by support.

Returns:

average weighted f1

Return type:

float

property weighted_precision: float#

Computes the precision for each label, and find their average weighted by support.

Returns:

average weighted precision

Return type:

float

property weighted_recall: float#

Computes the recall for each label, and find their average weighted by support.

Returns:

average weighted recall

Return type:

float

class bert_squeeze.utils.scorers.scorer_fast.FastBertScorer(n_labels: int)[source]#

Helper class to compute various evaluation metrics for the FastBert models.

This Scorer is different from the ones in the scorer.py as it computes metrics for the different branches of the model. We store metrics in a dict fashion where the key is the layer and the value are the different metrics.

Parameters:

n_labels (int) – number of available labels

property acc: Dict[str, float]#
Computes the accuracy score for the different layers:

number of correct predictions / number of predictions

Returns:

accuracy score for the different layers

Return type:

Dict[str,float]

add(logits: Tensor | List[Tensor], labels: Tensor, loss: FastBertLoss | None = None, ignored_label: int = -100) → None[source]#

Updates the confusion matrix by using the predictions and the ground truth labels and keeps track of the loss.

Parameters:

  • logits (Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]]) – predicted logits, depending on the training stage we are in they are either of type torch.Tensor (if training_stage=0) which corresponds to the logits of the last classifier. Or of type List[torch.Tensor] (if training_stage=1) which corresponds to the logits of all the layers.

  • labels (torch.Tensor) – ground truth labels

  • loss (FastBertLoss) – computed loss

  • ignored_label (int) – value to ignore during metric computation, default to -100 (PyTorch ignored value)

property f1: Dict[str, array]#
Computes the f1 scores for every layer for each class using the following formula:

F1 = 2 * (precision * recall) / (precision + recall)

Returns:

f1 scores for the different layers

Return type:

Dict[str, np.array]

get_table() → str[source]#

Method to format all the metrics into a pretty table.

Returns:

prettyfied table summarizing all the metrics

Return type:

str

property precision: Dict[str, array]#
Computes the precision scores for every layer for each class using the following formula:

tp / (tp + fp)

Returns:

precision scores for the different layers

Return type:

Dict[str, np.array]

property recall: Dict[str, array]#
Computes the recall scores for every layer for each class using the following formula:

tp / (tp + fn)

Returns:

recall score for the different layers

Return type:

Dict[str, np.array]

reset() → None[source]#

Resets the confusion matrix, batch counter and losses. This method should be called after logging metrics.
